text: - Hello and welcome to community chats.
I'm Aley Hammer,

and today we're interviewing
Dr. Michael Bewley,

the Senior Director of
AI Systems at Nearmap.
Michael, welcome to the show.
Can you start by telling our audience

a little bit about Nearmap
and how you guys use AWS?
- Hey Aley, thanks for having me.
Look, Nearmap is a technology company.

In fact, we call ourselves
a deep tech company
because we do everything from the design

and construction of these
aerial imagery cameras,
through to putting them in planes
and capturing vast amounts of imagery,
turning that into visual content,
making it available to customers,
and now even doing location intelligence.

So producing machine
learning-derived outputs
for customers to understand the world.

So we do that end to end,
and we've been doing it for,
(contemplates)

more than a decade now, and
we do it in four countries,
so Australia, US, Canada, and New Zealand.
And it's all about the built environment.
So cities, major towns,

we're covering I think
80% of the US population
at least once a year,

90% of the Australian
population and so on.

So it's a really big
consistent capture program
built on some pretty amazing technology.
- Phenomenal scale,
and your business is literally changing
the way we look at the world,

because people no longer have
to physically get in their car
or their plane to check out a site.

You're allowing amazing
visualization of areas
that are really hard to reach.
So, Michael, how does AWS help you
to support your customers?
- That's a really good question.

And it speaks a little to
the history of our company
and what makes us different.

So aerial imagery has been
for a long time quite bespoke.

You might order a capture
of your town or city
at a particular point in time,

and our discs might
arrive over coming months.
What Nearmap has been able to do

is to turn that into a
subscription-based business model

because we can capture more
efficiently than other people.
We can fly higher and faster.
We get this really repeatable program,

and if you're gonna have a
repeatable, consistent program,

that has to be built on
a really stable base.
So AWS is pretty key for us.

We've gotta store petabytes
and petabytes of imagery.

I can't remember how many
petabytes we're up to now,
but it's tens of petabytes.
We have to turn that into visual products,
like 3D reconstructions of whole cities,

and that takes a fair bit
of compute, let me tell you.

We run deep learning
models at massive scale,
so we're pulling GPUs from the cloud,
spinning up whole loads of compute
just to run and build these datasets,

and then we make 'em
available to customers.
So we've got lightning fast APIs,
we've got these interactive,
we've got this map browser tool

where people can click and
they can measure buildings
and all sorts of things in the world.
And all of that really works well.
If you wanna be an international company
doing that in a reliable way,
you need a base like AWS

that can alight a
transition between regions,

have lots of seamless
interconnected services,

but most importantly
give us the flexibility
to build what we want on top,

because we're trying to push
boundaries with our technology.

That's not about just
taking what's off the shelf,
but it's really pushing the boundaries
of what's possible.
- Well, after that answer,
it's absolutely clear

why you guys are one of the
biggest aerial imaging companies
in the whole world,

and I'm so glad that
you partnered with AWS
to help you scale your business.

So, Michael, what insights
can you actually generate
from this imagery?

'Cause I know you've got petabytes
and petabytes of imagery.
What do you do with it all?

- Yeah, so we used to just
do our visual products,

and then we moved to, so
that's looking at top down
or multiple angles and going back in time,

which is a pretty powerful
thing in and of itself.
Then we moved to 3D
and doing 3D reconstructions,
and now we're in the next phase,
which is around location intelligence.
So we run deep learning models

and all sorts of other
algorithms on top of our imagery

to capture a whole lot
of semantic information
about the world and what's out there.

One example, just one that
we've looked at recently,
relates to sustainable cities quite well.
It's looking at tree canopy.

So we run our AI models on
every survey that we fly.

So we did this project
where we just pulled
one layer of our trees

across all of the populated
parts of Australia

that we capture, and we
analyze the tree canopy cover

in all the Australian capital
cities and major towns,

and we're able to give
some real first numbers
because they've never been done before

with a consistent methodology
at really high resolution.
So it's pretty amazing to be able

to just pull a bunch of data
from an API and analyze it,
and for that to be new facts
that you find out about the world.
- Yeah, absolutely.
It's really cool to actually speak to you

and hear about the
evolution of the business,
'cause as you said, like,

the first step was boots on
the ground looking at imagery,
but beyond this,

your company has actually had
a huge transformational change

with location intelligence,
so really interesting stuff.
And Michael, you've touched on it already,
but as you mentioned with the trees,

you've been doing some
really interesting projects

around sustainable cities and
building sustainable cities,

so can you elaborate a
little bit more about that?
- Yeah, so that tree work that I mentioned

was really driven by a
number of our customers,
a large number, actually,

who were starting to ask
us questions about trees.
You know, we've built this AI model

which can produce dozens
and dozens of output layers,
but they were asking us,
tell us what our tree canopies like now,

tell us what it was like
five or 10 years ago,
and help us monitor it in future.

And what they're really
interested in doing

is dealing with a whole
bunch of things, actually.
One is urban heat islands.
So cities are getting hotter.

When you put a whole lot of
concrete and asphalt together
and get rid of all the trees,

that certainly has an
impact on temperatures.
I think you even see surface temperatures
differing by up to 10 degrees
between the middle of a dense city

and kind of the native
environment around it.

And so you see these
really localized effects
of it's not just about average tree canopy
across a whole area.

Even individual trees within
100 meters of your house
can have a really large cooling effect.

And there's other effects
that trees have, as well,
like mental health,

livability of areas, just the
perceptions of how people move
and understand and enjoy their spaces.

They're hugely impactful, so
it's a real pleasure for us

to be able to partner with
these government organizations

to help them monitor and
work with their communities

to ensure they have a really
nice sustainable, livable area.
- It's really easy to forget what came
before all this amazing technology,
'cause we used to rely on memory,
which can be so unreliable and incomplete.
So it's really fascinating

that you've got it all
documented over the years.
And lastly, Michael, I wanted to touch
on some of the amazing responses

you guys have actually had in
relation to natural disasters.

I mean, currently we're
going through huge floods,

so I know you've done some
incredible work around this.
So can you share some insights

around what you've been
doing in this amazing space?

- Yeah, natural disasters
are a big thing for Nearmap.
We've actually been capturing disasters

on top of our normal capture
program for a long time,

but we've recently formalized
as the ImpactResponse product,
and we run that in Australia and the US.
And what that really means

is instead of our
standard capture program,

where we'll get planes up a
few times a year in cities,
we actually chase and and look

at what the disasters
are that are happening,
and we get those planes up in the air
as soon as humanly possible.
You know, the logistics guys are looking
at exactly when the smoke clears

and when there's gonna be
enough space between the clouds

to get that plane up, whether
it's a flood or a fire
or some kind of wind event.

And then they're racing to
get the plane up in the air,
capture it, pull the imagery down,
process it and do all of that

to get it in the hands of
customers as fast as possible.

Because some of our customers
have really critical roles
in recovering from disaster.

We work a lot with insurers,
we work a lot with government,

and they're really
waiting with bated breath

to see what the outcome of
these disasters is gonna be.

And it's not just that
post-catastrophe flight.

So that's kind of the,
that's the race one.

But we also, because
we've already captured

a whole lot of areas and
we do that regularly,
you can see what was there beforehand,

so you can kind of look at
how things change over time.
And then we continue to monitor,

where you can see these really
beautiful stories unfolding
of after the disaster,
the recovery effort starts to come in

and those cities start
to rebuild themselves
and reshape themselves after the event.

- Michael, thank you so
much for the chat today.

If anyone needs any more
information, where can they go?

- Yeah, so probably the
best place is nearmap.com.
That's N-E-A-R-M-A-P.com.

You can find us on all the
standard social media channels.

And yeah, we look forward
to having you reach out
and have a chat, 'cause it's,
yeah, there's a lot that can be done
with our data out there,

and we love the possibilities
that our customers open up.
- Thank you so much, Michael.
- See you later.
